Tianjin University, Shaoxing, 312300, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work Mo-based catalysts are promising candidates for the de-methoxylation reaction in lignin valorization due to their unique behavior toward the cleavage of C–O bonds. However, the catalytic activities of Mo-based catalysts currently are still unsatisfactory and suffer from severe deactivation. Herein, we report a novel approach for the construction of robust Cu-modified Mo–SiO2 catalysts by sol-gel method through the synergistic effect of Cu and Mo, among which 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 with a Cu/Mo molar ratio of 0.33 exhibited the best catalytic performance for the de-methoxylation of lignin-derived 4-propylguaiacol. Remarkably, the space time yield of 4-propylphenol is among the highest value in literature data. The detailed characterizations confirm that the introduction of Cu by sol-gel method leads to the formation of highly dispersed CuMoO4 on the as-calcined samples, which results in the enhanced interaction between Cu and Mo species and the formation of a large amount of electron-deficient Mo0 on the as-reduced catalyst. Mechanistic studies reveal that electron-deficient Mo0 on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 will not only enhance the adsorption ability of substrate, but also improve the C–O bond cleavage ability for the de-methoxylation reaction. Meanwhile, the hydrogen spillover effect induced by Cu0 is beneficial to the enhancement of the catalytic activity and stability of 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 catalyst. Graphical abstract The Cu–Mo–SiO2 catalysts prepared by sol-gel method displayed remarkable catalytic activity and stability for the de-methoxylation of lignin-derived 4-propylguaiacol. Mechanistic studies demonstrated the synergistic effect of Cu and Mo species, in which Cu served as active sites for H2 dissociation, and Mo&MoO2 acted as active sites for the selective breaking of the CAr-OMe bond. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lignin valorization De-methoxylation Sol-gel method Mo-based catalyst Cu modification Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalytic conversion of lignocellulosic biomass into value-added chemicals and liquid fuels can satisfy the demands of sustainable human development [1,2]. Lignin, as one of the main components of lignocellulose, is the most abundant renewable aromatic source on Earth [3,4]. However, the degradation of lignin after traditional treatment method on lignocellulose render it normally as a low-grade solid fuel for heat generation [5]. In recent decades, reductive catalytic fractionation (RCF) has been recognized as an effective technology to preferentially depolymerize the lignin portion from lignocellulose with high retention of (hemi)cellulose [6–8]. The RCF technology can effectively prevent the degradation of lignin, and yield a narrow slate of lignin-derived phenolic monomers, such as 4-propylguaiacol (4-PG) [9,10]. Considering the enormous potential of RCF technology in biorefinery, lignin-derived phenolic monomers will represent as new bio-based platform molecules, serving as promising candidates for upgrading into valuable aromatic fine chemicals [11–13]. Alkylphenols are a group of high-value chemicals that are widely used as solvents, detergents, and thermoset polymers [14,15]. De-methoxylation of lignin-derived phenolic monomers is a promising method for the renewable production of alkylphenols [16–18]. Currently, different types of catalysts, such as noble metals and metal sulfides have been investigated [19,20]. Among them, non-noble Mo-based catalysts are promising for the selective de-methoxylation since they can selectively break the C–OMe bonds, leaving the phenolic hydroxyl groups and the phenyl groups intact [21–24]. For example, Yang et al. [13] found that MoO3/TiO2 displayed high selectivity for the de-methoxylation of guaiacol because the catalyst has high surface area, a large number of weak and medium acid sites, and a moderate oxygen vacancy concentration. However, the catalytic activity of Mo-based catalysts for the de-methoxylation reaction is still not satisfactory, and also suffers from serious deactivation [25,26]. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop efficient strategies to improve both the catalytic activity and stability of Mo-based catalysts for the de-methoxylation of lignin-derived phenolic monomers. The introduction of promoters, such as Cu, into Mo-based catalysts is an effective strategy to improve the catalytic activity for the de-methoxylation reaction [27]. For example, Dionizio et al. [28] demonstrated that metallic Cu species on Cu-MoO3-x/C would facilitate the H2 dissociation and promote the reduction of MoO3, which benefited the cleavage of C–O bonds in the hydrodeoxygenation of phenol. However, current research efforts primarily focus on the introduction of Cu into Mo-based catalysts by co-precipitation [29,30] and impregnation methods [27,28,31]. The as-synthesized catalysts suffer from the non-uniform dispersion of Cu species and the weak interaction between Cu and Mo species, which results in limited enhancement of the catalytic activity and stability. It is noteworthy that catalysts with uniformly dispersed Cu species normally exhibited excellent hydrogenation activity [32,33]. Also, the strong interaction between Cu and Mo species would inhibit the catalyst deactivation through the inhibition of coke formation [34,35]. As we all know, sol-gel method is an advanced technique to prepare catalysts with uniformly dispersed active sites and strong interaction between active sites and supports. For example, Zeng et al. [36] showed that CuO-TiO2 catalysts prepared by sol-gel method with highly dispersed Cu species and strong interaction between Cu and TiO2, which displayed improved catalytic activity and stability for selective catalytic oxidation of NO. Inspired by these advances, introducing Cu species into Mo-based catalysts by sol-gel method is a promising strategy to improve both the catalytic activity and stability for the de-methoxylation reaction, although it is rarely reported so far. Herein, a series of Cu–Mo–SiO2 catalysts with different Cu/Mo molar ratios was prepared by sol-gel method and then applied for the de-methoxylation of lignin-derived monomer 4-PG to 4-propylphenol (4-PP). The introduction of Cu into Mo–SiO2 by sol-gel method significantly improved the catalytic activity and stability for the de-methoxylation of 4-PG. Detailed characterizations were performed to study the changes of catalyst structure induced by the introduction of Cu and its influence on the catalytic performance for the de-methoxylation reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The mCu–Mo–SiO2 catalysts were prepared by sol-gel method (where m represents the Cu/Mo molar ratio). Typically, 10.41 g TEOS was mixed with 4.71 g isopropanol to obtain the silanol solution. Subsequently, 1.23 g (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and 0.56 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O were dissolved in 30 mL deionized water. Afterwards, the aqueous metal solution was added dropwise to the silanol solution and stirred at 70 °C for 100 min. Finally, the resulting gel was aged at room temperature for 48 h, dried at 120 °C for 8 h, and then calcined at 500 °C with a ramping rate of 2 °C·min−1 for 4 h to obtain 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2. The reduced catalysts were obtained by treating the as-calcined catalysts at 400 ∼ 580 °C for 1 h under a pure H2 flow (50 mL·min−1). For comparison, the Mo–SiO2 catalyst was prepared using sol-gel method according to the same synthesis procedures as for mCu–Mo–SiO2 except that no Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was added. The 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2 catalyst was prepared by impregnation method. Typically, 0.56 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 4.0 g Mo–SiO2 were added to 200 mL of water and stirred at room temperature for 3 h. Afterwards, the obtained suspension was dried at 120 °C for 8 h, following by calcining at 500 °C for 4 h to obtain the 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2 catalyst. The Cu–SiO2 and Cu/SiO2 catalysts were prepared using sol-gel and impregnation method respectively according to the same synthesis procedures as for 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 and 0.33Cu-Mo/SiO2 except that no Mo precursor was added. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) of samples were recorded on a Bruker D8 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm) at a scanning speed of 10° min−1 (2θ = 10° to 80°). In situ XRD were performed using a Rigaku smartlab (Cu–Ka λ = 0.1542 nm) X-ray diffractometer. The sample was raised from room temperature to target temperature at a heating ramp of 10 °C·min−1 in a H2 flow (99.999 %, 20 mL·min−1), and then remained at this temperature for 1 h. Finally, the diffraction patterns were obtained in the 2θ range from 10° and 80° (scanning speed: 10°·min−1). The Mo and Cu loading in each catalyst were measured from elemental analysis using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Thermo Scientific iCAP7400). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images, high resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) images and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mappings results were conducted by a JEM-F200 microscope. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) characterization was carried out on a Quantachrome QuadraSorb SI analyzer at –196 °C. Before testing, catalysts were degassed under vacuum at 300 °C for 3 h to remove impurities and moisture adsorbed on the surface. The specific surface area was measured by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the pore size distribution was determined by the BJH method (based on N2 desorption isotherm). The reducibility of the as-calcined catalysts was determined by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) technique on a XianQuan TP-5080 analyzer. Catalysts (30 mg) were pretreated under N2 at 500 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to room temperature. When the thermal conductivity signal value was essentially unchanged, the H2-TPR profiles were collected under 10 vol% H2 in N2 (30 mL·min−1) from 50 °C to 900 °C using a temperature ramp of 10 °C·min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha+X spectrometer with an Al Kα radiation Binding energy corrections were taken using C1s (284.8 eV). Thermogravimetric analysis (after the stability test of the catalysts) was determined on an STA7300 thermogravimetric instruments. the catalyst (10 mg) was pretreated under N2 at 120 °C for 2 h to eliminate the water and organic matter on the catalyst surface, and then then cooled to room temperature. the TGA profiles were recorded using air gas (100 mL·min−1) from 50 °C to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min−1. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) of anisole were performed on XianQuan TP-5079 analyzer equipped with a quartz tube (inner diameter of 6 mm). Typically, 100 mg of sample was loaded into the tube and reduced in situ under a H2 flow (30 mL·min−1) at 580 °C for 1 h (ramping rate 10 °C·min−1). Afterward, the as-reduced sample was cooled down to 50 °C and adsorbed anisole with N2 flow (30 mL·min−1) for 10 min, followed by purging with N2 for 30 min to remove physically adsorbed anisole. Anisole-TPD was conducted by hearting samples from 50 to 400 °C under a N2 flow at a ramping rate of 10 °C·min−1. Anisole-TPSR was carried out by heating samples under H2/N2 flow (10 vol%, 30 mL·min−1) at a ramping rate of 5 °C·min−1. The effluent flow was monitored by a mass spectrometer (Hiden HPR-20). All as-reduced samples were pretreated in H2 (50 mL·min−1) on XianQuan TP-5079 at 580 °C for 1 h (ramping rate 10 °C·min−1). Prior to the tests, the as-reduced samples were passivated in 1 % O2/Ar (40 mL·min−1) for 20 min, followed by vacuum sealing to prevent further oxidation. 2.3 Activity test The de-methoxylation of 4-PG was performed in a continuous fixed-bed reactor equipped with a quartz tube (outer diameter 20 mm, inner diameter 10 mm, length 390 mm). Typically, 40 mg of catalyst with a bulk density of ∼ 0.13 g·mL−1 was fixed in the middle of the quartz tube using silica wool, and reduced in situ at a set temperature for 1 h under a H2 flow (50 mL·min−1). The reaction was started when the reactor cooled down to the desired temperature, followed by feeding 4-PG at the desired weighted hourly space velocity (WHSV, h−1) using a syringe pump (TYD01-02). Specifically, the feeding rate of 4-PG was 3236 nL·min−1 at a WHSV of 5 h−1. The reaction products were collected by ethyl acetate in a condenser equipped with an ice-water recirculation system at 1 h intervals and then analyzed offline using GC-FID (Shimadzu 2010C gas chromatograph equipped with an HP-5 capillary column). Tridecane was added to the reaction products as an internal standard to determine the conversion and selectivity. The conversion of 4-PG and the selectivity of a product i were calculated using Eqs. (1) and (2). (1) X 4 − PG ( % ) = 1 − n 4 − PG n 4 − PG , 0 × 100 (2) S i ( % ) = n i n 4 − PG , 0 − n 4 − PG × 100 Here, Xi, Si, n4-PG,0, n4-PG and ni represent the conversion of 4-PG, the selectivity of specific products, the molar amount of 4-PG in the feed, the molar amount of 4-PG remaining after reaction, and the molar amount of specific products, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation of mCu–Mo–SiO2 using sol-gel method The mCu–Mo–SiO2 samples (where m represents the Cu/Mo molar ratio) are synthesized by sol-gel method [37] as illustrated in Scheme 1 . Typically, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was first dissolved into isopropanol solution, and then added dropwise to the aqueous solution containing Mo6+ and Cu2+ species under vigorous stirring, which enabled the uniform dispersion of Cu2+ and Mo6+ species in the SiO2 gel. Afterwards, the obtained gel was aged, dried, calcined, and reduced to give as-reduced mCu–Mo–SiO2 samples. 3.2 Properties of as-calcined samples The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-calcined Mo–SiO2 and mCu–Mo–SiO2 are shown in Fig. 1 (a). All these samples displayed the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 12.8°, 23.3°, 25.7°, 27.2°, 33.7°, 39.0°, 45.8°, 46.4°, and 49.3°, which could be assigned to an orthorhombic phase of MoO3 (JCPDS card no. 89-7112) [38]. For mCu–Mo–SiO2, when the molar ratio of Cu/Mo reached up to 0.17, the additional diffraction peaks at 2θ = 15.8°, 23.8°, 26.4°, 26.8°, 29.5°, and 32.9° were observed, corresponding to the α-CuMoO4 phase (JCPDS card no. 73-0488) [39]. Meanwhile, the ratio of CuMoO4/MoO3 gradually increased with increasing the molar ratio of Cu/Mo from 0.17 to 1.00 (Table S1). The very weak diffraction peaks of MoO3 and CuMoO4 in 1.00Cu–Mo–SiO2 indicate that too high Cu content would destroy the crystal structure of sample. Similar phenomenon was also observed on 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2 prepared by impregnation method. In addition, the small diffraction peaks belonging to CuO (JCPDS card no. 45-0937) were observed in mCu–Mo–SiO2 with a Cu/Mo molar ratio above 0.17 [29]. Fig. 1(b)-(c) shows the EDX mappings of the as-calcined 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2, respectively. It was observed that Cu and Mo elements were uniformly distributed on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2, indicating that the sample prepared by sol-gel method resulted in the uniform dispersion of MoO3 and CuMoO4 species. In contrast, an obvious aggregation of Cu species was observed on 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the as-calcined samples are shown in Fig. S1. All samples displayed type-IV isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating the formation of mesoporous structure. Table 1 summarizes the structural properties of different as-calcined samples. During the preparation of mCu–Mo–SiO2 samples, the amount of MoO3 and SiO2 was kept constant, while the amount of Cu was added based on the different Cu/Mo molar ratios. Accordingly, the content of Mo gradually decreased from 16.5 to 14.8 wt% with increasing the content of Cu. For mCu–Mo–SiO2, with increasing the molar ratio of Cu/Mo, the specific surface area (SBET) of mCu–Mo–SiO2 increased gradually, while the average pore diameter (Dp) and pore volume (Vp) of mCu–Mo–SiO2 decreased, possibly resulting from the formation of CuMoO4 species. The above results indicate that the introduction of Cu could modify the structural properties of mCu–Mo–SiO2 samples. 3.3 In-situ XRD characterization results In situ XRD patterns are performed to study the structural change of Mo–SiO2 and 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 samples under different reduction temperatures (Fig. 2 ). Fig. 2(a) shows in situ XRD patterns of Mo–SiO2 with increasing the reduction temperature from 400 to 580 °C. After reduction at 400 °C, Mo–SiO2-400 only displayed the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 25.9°, 36.9°, 53.4°, 60.1°, and 66.5°, belonging to (110), (020), (–311), (130), and (–231) planes of MoO2 (JCPDS card no. 04-003-1961) [40], respectively. That is to say, a direct reduction of MoO3 to MoO2 occurred during the reduction process. When the reduction temperature was increased to 580 °C, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 40.3° belonging to the (110) crystal plane of metallic Mo (JCPDS card no. 97-005-2267) [41] appeared, suggesting the further reduction of MoO2 to Mo. Fig. 2(b) shows in situ XRD patterns of 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 with increasing the reduction temperature from 400 to 580 °C. For 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-400, the presence of Cu and Cu2O species were observed, in which the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 42.9°, 49.9°, and 73.4° and 2θ = 37.9°, 44.0°, and 64.1° corresponded to Cu (JCPDS card no. 04-001-3178) [42] and Cu2O (JCPDS card no. 77-0199) [43], respectively. Moreover, the patterns showed the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 26.0°, 36.9°, and 53.4°, corresponding to the (110), (020), and (–311) crystal planes of MoO2 (JCPDS card no. 04-003-1961). No characteristic diffraction peaks belonging to MoO3, CuMoO4, and CuO were detected after reduction at 400 °C, indicating that Mo6+ and Cu2+ species were totally reduced to Mo4+ and Cu0&Cu+ species. Interestingly, increasing the reduction temperature to 550 °C, the diffraction peaks of metallic Mo were observed in 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-550. In contrast, no metallic Mo was observed on Mo–SiO2 after reduction at 550 °C (Fig. 2(a)). Moreover, the intensity of metallic Mo diffraction peak significantly increased with further increasing the reduction temperature to 580 °C. Therefore, we can conclude that the introduction of Cu by sol-gel method will significantly promote the reduction of MoO2 to Mo. Since the introduction of Cu by impregnation method would destroy the crystal structure of CuMoO4 and MoO3, the intensities of diffraction peaks belonging to Mo&MoO2 and Cu&Cu2O in 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 were much lower than that in 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 (Fig. S2). 3.4 Properties of as-reduced samples The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of Mo–SiO2-580, 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580, and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 samples are shown in Fig. 3 (a)–(c). The spacing lattice fringes of 0.240 and 0.329 nm were observed on Mo–SiO2-580, corresponding to the (110) and (020) crystal planes of MoO2, respectively. For 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580, the spacing lattice fringes of 0.209 and 0.222 nm corresponded to the (111) crystal plane of Cu and the (110) crystal plane of Mo, which was consistent with the XRD results in Fig. 2. Similarly, the spacing lattice fringes belonging to the (110) crystal plane of Mo and the (111) crystal plane of Cu were also observed on 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580. The energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mappings of three as-reduced samples are shown in Fig. 3(d)–(i). The uniform dispersion of Mo and/or Cu elements were observed on Mo–SiO2-580 and 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580. In contrast, the obvious aggregation of Cu species was found on 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580. In addition, the particle size of MoO2 on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 was slightly larger than that on Mo–SiO2-580 (Fig. S3), possibly resulting from the formation of CuMoO4. The physical properties of the as-reduced samples are summarized in Table S2. Compared with the as-calcined samples (Table 1), an obvious increase in the SBET was observed on the as-reduced samples. Normally, the reduction of metal oxides on the calcined samples will result in an enlargement of the SBET due to the formation of small and dispersed metal species [44,45]. In contrast, the reduction process has a very slight effect on the structure of SiO2 support. Accordingly, very small changes in the Dp and Vp were observed between the as-calcined and as-reduced samples. Similar to the as-calcined samples, with increasing the molar ratio of Cu/Mo, the SBET of the as-reduced samples gradually increased, while their Dp and Vp decreased. The above characterization results show that the introduction of Cu to Mo–SiO2 by sol-gel method will result in the formation of highly dispersed CuMoO4, which is not available to the sample prepared by impregnation method. Meanwhile, a significant improvement in the reduction of MoO2 to Mo is observed on Cu–Mo–SiO2 prepared by sol-gel method. Accordingly, the uniform distribution of Mo and Cu species and a large amount of Mo0 appear in the as-reduced samples, which may result in different catalytic behaviors towards the de-methoxylation of 4-PG. 3.5 Catalytic performance of mCu–Mo–SiO2 3.5.1 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of different catalysts for the de-methoxylation of 4-PG is evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor and the results are summarized in Table 2 . Mo–SiO2-580 showed very poor catalytic activity with a conversion of 45.2 % and a selectivity of 72.5 % at conditions of 330 °C, WHSV of 5 h−1, and time-on-stream of 4 h. Interestingly, the introduction of Cu into Mo–SiO2 could improve their catalytic activity. The conversion of 46.1 % and a selectivity of 75.9 % were obtained over 0.08Cu–Mo–SiO2-580. With increasing the molar ratio of Cu/Mo to 0.33, the maximum conversion of 88.3 % with a selectivity of 79.0 % was obtained over 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580. Further increasing the Cu loading, the conversion over 1.00Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 decreased to 69.1 %, while the selectivity of 4-PP increased to 81.8 %. As a reference catalyst, 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 was prepared by impregnation of Mo–SiO2 with copper nitrate. Compared with Mo–SiO2-580, the conversion over 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 only slightly increased to 66.0 %. In addition, no catalytic activity was observed over Cu–SiO2-580 and Cu/SiO2-580 in the de-methoxylation of 4-PG (Fig. S4), indicating that Cu species do not serve as active sites for the cleavage of C–O bonds. The above results indicate that the introduction of Cu to Mo–SiO2 by sol-gel method can significantly improve their catalytic activity for the de-methoxylation of 4-PG. Moreover, upon the introduction of Cu, the space time yield of 4-PP (STY4-PP) over mCu–Mo–SiO2-580 showed a significant increase compared with that on Mo–SiO2-580. Notably, 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 exhibited the maximum STY4-PP of 2.852 g·gcat −1·h−1 at 330 °C and WHSV of 5 h−1 (Table 2), which is higher than most of other reported catalysts (Table S3). In addition to the target product 4-PP, the by-products, such as alkylphenols and aromatic hydrocarbons, were identified by gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC-MS) (Fig. S5). Propylbenzene and 4-propyl-2-methylphenol were detected as the main by-products, which were possibly produced by dehydration and alkylation of 4-PP, respectively. Based on the distributions of products and references, a possible reaction network was established and shown in Fig. S6 [3,14]. 3.5.2 Effect of reaction temperature Fig. 4 (a) shows the effect of reaction temperature on the de-methoxylation of 4-PG over 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580. As expected, the conversion of 4-PG increased with increasing the reaction temperature from 270 to 330 °C. Further increasing the reaction temperature to 350 °C, the conversion of 4-PG slowly increased to 89.5 %, possibly resulting from the competing reaction on active sites, such as the dehydration of 4-PP to propylbenzene. Similarly, the selectivity of 4-PP increased from 79.6 % to 84.9 % with increasing the reaction temperature from 270 to 310 °C. Further increasing the reaction temperature, the selectivity of 4-PP decreased and the selectivity of propylbenzene increased, which was mainly attributed to the dehydration of 4-PP to propylbenzene at high temperatures. Fig. 4(b) shows the effect of WHSV (3 ∼ 7 h−1) on the de-methoxylation of 4-PG at a H2 flow rate of 50 mL·min−1. The conversion of 4-PG decreased from 91.2 % to 60.7 % when WHSV was increased from 3 to 7 h−1. In contrast, the selectivity of 4-PP increased with increasing WHSV. The contact time of 4-PP on the catalyst surface becomes shorter with increasing WHSV, and accordingly inhibits the further conversion of 4-PP to propylbenzene. Finally, the highest yield of 4-PP was obtained at a WHSV of 5 h−1. 3.5.3 Kinetic and stability tests According to the Arrhenius plots displayed in Fig. 5 (a), the apparent activation energy (Ea) for the de-methoxylation reaction over 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 (72.2 kJ·mol−1) was similar to that over Mo–SiO2-580 (73.1 kJ·mol−1). Previous works indicate that the cleavage of C–O bonds is the rate-determining step for the de-methoxylation reaction [46,47]. That is to say, the cleavage of C–O bonds may still occur at Mo–based sites regardless of whether Cu species are introduced or not. However, the conversion over 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 was much higher than that over Mo–SiO2-580 (Table 2). Thus, we infer that Cu0 in 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 serve as active sites for H2 activation rather than for the cleavage of C–O bonds, which possibly facilitates the de-methoxylation of 4-PG through hydrogen spillover. Fig. 5(b) shows the long-term stability test of different catalysts. At a time-on-stream of 8 h, the conversion of 4-PG over 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580, 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580, and Mo–SiO2-580 was 88.3 %, 50.7 %, and 31.6 %, respectively, indicating that the deactivation over Mo–SiO2-580 and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 was more severe than that over 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580. For 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580, the conversion slightly decreased from 96.4 % to 67.6 % after 20 h. In contrast, the conversion significantly decreased from 91.8 % to 31.3 % over 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 after 20 h. Importantly, the catalytic performance of the spent 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 catalyst could be easily regenerated by calcination and reduction, indicating that the catalytic deactivation was possibly attributed to the carbon deposition. TGA profiles of 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 after long-term stability test (20 h) are shown in Fig. 5(c). Notably, an abnormal increase in weight (%) was observed on the spent catalysts, possibly resulting from the oxidization of the as-reduced Mo and Cu species during TG analysis. The amount of coke on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 was ∼ 1.3 wt%, which was much lower than that on 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 (∼ 5.0 wt%). The above results indicate that the introduction of Cu to Mo–SiO2 by sol-gel method can also improve its catalytic stability through the inhibition of coke formation. 3.5.4 Effect of reduction temperature The effect of reduction temperature on the de-methoxylation of 4-PG over Mo–SiO2 and 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 is further investigated. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), with increasing the reduction temperature from 400 to 580 °C, the conversion of 4-PG over Mo–SiO2 gradually increased, and the gradual transformation from MoO2 to Mo in Mo–SiO2 also occurred based on the XRD results in Fig. 2(a). Similarly, the conversion of 4-PG over 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 increased with increasing the reduction temperature (Fig. 6(b)). As shown in Fig. 2(b), with increasing the reduction temperature, the intensity of Cu0 diffraction peak in 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 almost kept constant, while the intensity of Mo0 diffraction peak gradually increased. Previous works indicated that the increase in the oxygenophilicity of the active site will reduce the energy barrier for the cleavage of C–O bonds [47,48]. Therefore, we infer that Mo0 serve as new active sites for the cleavage of C–O bonds due to the fact that the oxygenophilicity of Mo is higher than that of MoO2. 3.6 H2-TPR analysis The reducibility of the as-calcined Mo–SiO2, 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2, and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2 is investigated by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) (Fig. 7 (a)). For Mo–SiO2, two major reduction peaks at 534 °C (β) and 742 °C (γ) were observed, corresponding to the reduction of MoO3 to MoO2 and MoO2 to Mo, respectively [49]. For 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2, the introduction of Cu resulted in a new reduction peak (α) at ∼ 320 °C, which was possibly assigned to the reduction of CuMoO4. Compared with Mo–SiO2, the β reduction peak of 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2 shifted to much lower temperature (∼ 350 °C). The XRD results in Fig. 2(b) confirm the formation of Cu0 in the as-reduced 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2 samples, which enable the reduction of MoO3 at low temperature through hydrogen spillover. However, the γ reduction peak of 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2 slightly shifted to higher temperature compared with Mo–SiO2, possibly due to the large MoO2 particle sizes (Fig. S3). 3.7 XPS studies The surface compositions of Mo–SiO2-580, 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580, and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 are investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The deconvoluted XPS spectra of Mo 3d orbitals suggested the coexistence of Mo0, Mo4+, Mo5+, and Mo6+ species in these catalysts (Fig. 7(b)) [50]. The percentage of Mo0 in 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 was much higher than that in 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 and Mo–SiO2-580, which was in accordance with the XRD results in Figs. 2 and S2. As shown in Table S4, upon addition of Cu, the Mo0 3d peaks of 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 shifted to higher binding energy. The uniform distribution of Mo and Cu elements in Fig. 3 indicate the presence of the interaction between Mo0 and Cu0. Also, the work function of Mo0 (4.60 eV) is lower than that of Cu0 (4.65 eV). Thus, we can conclude that there exists electron transfer from Mo0 to Cu0. In contrast, such a shift was not observed on 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580, possibly resulting from its non-uniform distribution of Cu0. Therefore, the introduction of Cu by sol-gel method not only significantly promote the formation of Mo0, but also induce the formation of electron-deficient Mo0 [51]. Since 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 and Mo–SiO2-580 exhibit comparable amounts of Mo0 and Mo4+, the enhanced catalytic activity over 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 possibly results from the hydrogen spillover effect induced by Cu0. In addition, no satellite peaks of Cu2+ species were observed in the Cu 2p XPS spectra on both two catalysts (Fig. S7(a)), indicating the complete reduction of CuO into Cu0&Cu+ species [51]. Cu LMM Auger spectra are also performed to distinguish Cu0 and Cu+ species on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580. As shown in Fig. S7(b), two symmetrical peaks at 916.6 eV and 918.7 eV were assigned to Cu0 and Cu+ species, respectively [51]. Compared with 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580, a relatively higher ratio of Cu0/Cu+ was observed on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580. Hence, 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 may exhibit an enhanced hydrogen spillover effect, which accordingly improves its catalytic activity and stability for the de-methoxylation of 4-PG. It is noted that the presence of Mo5+ and Mo6+ species was possibly attributed to the partial oxidation during the preparation of ex situ samples [52]. 3.8 Anisole-TPD and Anisole-TPSR experiments To gain deep insight into differences in catalytic activity among different catalysts, temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) and temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) are conducted with anisole as a methoxy-containing aromatic model compound. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), the similar temperature (T = 69 °C) for the on-set of anisole desorption was observed on Mo–SiO2-580 and 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580, while a higher temperature (T = 75 °C) was observed on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580, suggesting its enhanced adsorption of anisole. Moreover, the area of the desorption peak followed the order: 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 >> 0.33Cu/Mo–SiO2-580 > Mo–SiO2-580 (Table S5). It is noteworthy that Cu-SiO2-580 and SiO2 support displayed similar desorption profiles (Fig. S8), suggesting that Cu species were ineffective for the adsorption of anisole. Combined with XPS results in Fig. 7(b), we can conclude that Mo0 serves as adsorption sites for the substrate, and the adsorption strength of the substrate is enhanced on electron-deficient Mo0. As shown in Fig. 8(b)-(c), compared with Mo–SiO2-580 (∼ 65 °C), the de-methoxylation of anisole to benzene and methanol via the cleavage of C–O bonds on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 started at a lower temperature (∼ 60 °C), indicating its stronger ability to cleave C–O bonds. Meanwhile, the area ratio of benzene/anisole on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 was much higher than that on Mo–SiO2-580 (Table S6), which was consistent with its improved catalytic activity in the de-methoxylation reaction. In addition, no cyclohexane was detected on both 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 and Mo–SiO2-580, indicating the poor ability of Mo species for aromatic ring hydrogenation. Therefore, we infer that Mo0 serves as active sites for the de-methoxylation reaction and the formation of electron-deficient Mo0 will significantly enhance the adsorption ability of substrate, and accordingly improve the ability toward the cleavage of C–O bonds in the de-methoxylation reaction. 3.9 Proposed mechanism Based on the above results, a plausible reaction mechanism for the de-methoxylation of 4-PG on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 is proposed and illustrated in Scheme 2 . The existence of MoO2 in both Mo–SiO2-580 and 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 suggests that MoO2 still serves as active sites for the cleavage of C–O bonds in the de-methoxylation of 4-PG, which was also in accordance with references [50,53–55]. For 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580, the introduction of Cu to Cu-SiO2 by sol-gel method induces the formation of a large amount of electron-deficient Mo0. The electron-deficient Mo0 on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 will not only enhance the adsorption of substrate, but also improve the C–O bond cleavage ability in the de-methoxylation reaction. Moreover, the hydrogen spillover effect induced by Cu0 will improve the catalytic activity and stability of 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 in the de-methoxylation reaction. In addition, Cu2O was possibly not involved in the de-methoxylation reaction due to its poor H2 dissociation ability. Therefore, the enhanced catalytic activity over 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 was mainly attributed to the synergistic effect of Mo0 and MoO2 and hydrogen spillover induced by Cu0, while the improved catalytic stability mainly resulted from the inhibition of coke formation caused by hydrogen spillover. 4 Conclusion In summary, we developed Cu–Mo–SiO2 catalysts with different Cu/Mo molar ratios using sol-gel method, among which 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 exhibited the best catalytic performance for the de-methoxylation of 4-PG into 4-PP, displaying 88.3 % conversion and 79.0 % selectivity at 330 °C and 5 h−1 (WHSV). The XRD results indicate that the introduction of Cu to Mo–SiO2 by sol-gel method leads to the formation of highly dispersed CuMoO4 on the ac-calcined catalysts. In situ XRD, TEM, and XPS results demonstrate that the enhanced interaction between Mo and Cu species and a large amount of electron-deficient Mo0 appear on the as-reduced catalysts. TPD and TPSR results verify that electron-deficient Mo0 will significantly enhance the adsorption ability of substrate and improve the C–O bond cleavage ability in the de-methoxylation reaction. The kinetic studies suggest that Cu0 mainly serves as active sites for H2 activation to improve the catalytic activity and stability via hydrogen spillover. The present work shows the great potential for the construction of electron-deficient Mo0 sites for the cleavage of C–O bonds in lignin valorization. coredata.dc:description: Mo-based catalysts are promising candidates for the de-methoxylation reaction in lignin valorization due to their unique behavior toward the cleavage of C–O bonds. However, the catalytic activities of Mo-based catalysts currently are still unsatisfactory and suffer from severe deactivation. Herein, we report a novel approach for the construction of robust Cu-modified Mo–SiO2 catalysts by sol-gel method through the synergistic effect of Cu and Mo, among which 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 with a Cu/Mo molar ratio of 0.33 exhibited the best catalytic performance for the de-methoxylation of lignin-derived 4-propylguaiacol. Remarkably, the space time yield of 4-propylphenol is among the highest value in literature data. The detailed characterizations confirm that the introduction of Cu by sol-gel method leads to the formation of highly dispersed CuMoO4 on the as-calcined samples, which results in the enhanced interaction between Cu and Mo species and the formation of a large amount of electron-deficient Mo0 on the as-reduced catalyst. Mechanistic studies reveal that electron-deficient Mo0 on 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 will not only enhance the adsorption ability of substrate, but also improve the C–O bond cleavage ability for the de-methoxylation reaction. Meanwhile, the hydrogen spillover effect induced by Cu0 is beneficial to the enhancement of the catalytic activity and stability of 0.33Cu–Mo–SiO2-580 catalyst.

coredata.dc:title: Synergistic effect of Cu and Mo over Cu–Mo–SiO2 catalyst prepared by sol-gel method for high-efficient and stable de-methoxylation of lignin-derived 4-propylguaiacol
